data.title: Best Australian Tennis Players of All Time, Highest Ranked Players In Pictures: Australia's top-ranked tennis stars since 1990
data.meta_description: Since 1990, Australia has had three world No.1s and a raft of others have cracked the top-10 – Alex De Minaur the most recent. Wide World of Sports ﻿has the list.
data.text:
Australia's top-ranked tennis players since 1990

Despite its small population, Australia has always punched above its weight in sport.

Tennis is no different.

Since 1990, Australia has had three world No.1s and a raft of others have cracked the top-10 – Alex De Minaur the most recent.

So who are the others that have cracked the top-40? Can you name all of them?

Wide World of Sports has the list.

19. Todd Woodbridge

Although they were perfectly in-sync when on the court, it's still a little spooky both Woodies reached a career-high singles ranking of No.19.

As they were in doubles, it was on grass Woodbridge was most dangerous, and it was at Wimbledon where he achieved most of his singles career highlights.

He's one of only seven people to beat Pete Sampras at the All-England club, and is also one of only 17 players to inflict a triple bagel defeat in the open era. He beat swede Johan Örtegren 6-0, 6-0, 6-0 in the final round of qualifying in 2001.

He also made a semi-final appearance in 1997, but lost in straight-sets to Sampras, who went on to win.

That semi-final lifted him to his career-high No.19.

Woodbridge is one of Nine's leading tennis analysts and sports broadcasters.

17. Bernard Tomic

In what is a strong example of a player failing to fulfil his talent, Bernard Tomic absolutely dominated as a junior.

He won two junior slams and began competing in men's competition full-time aged just 16.

He reached his career-high singles ranking of No.17 in January 2016, just days before he began his run to the fourth round of the Australian Open, which would be an equal-best showing.

Injury struggles began not long after though, and his decline proper began in 2017. Having made the third round at the Australian Open, Tomic bombed out in the first round at each of the other slams. His decline from then on is well-documented.

13. Nick Kyrgios

Having burst onto the scene in 2014, Nick Kyrgios looked for all money to be the next big thing in Australian tennis.

He beat then world No.1 Rafael Nadal to make the Wimbledon quarterfinals, and won his first ATP event soon after.

He's since claimed seven ATP titles, and famously made the 2022 Wimbledon final.

He reached his career-high ranking of No.13 in October 2016.

His hot temper, apparent indifference towards tennis and fickle relationship with the media has earned him a level of notoriety among fans, although many close to him have stated his persona behind the scenes is a polar opposite.

Still, he's one of if not the most entertaining players in men's tennis.

8. Mark Philippoussis

Mark Philippoussis was a part of a trio that led a golden era of Australian men's tennis.

The Scud was known for having one of the biggest serves in tennis, and won 11 ATP Titles in a fourteen-year career.

Philippoussis lost both his slam finals appearances – including all-Australian affair with Pat Rafter at the 1998 US Open final.

He peaked at No.8 the following April after a five-set victory against Carlos Moya to win Indian Wells - his only Masters Series title.

He made a brief comeback of sorts in 2015, but has mostly focussed on coaching.

Philippoussis has been working on-and-off with Greek star Stefanos Tsitsipas for the past several years.

4. Jelena Dokic

Still the only qualifier to ever beat a world No.1 at Wimbledon – achieving the feat as a 16-year-old in 1999.

Although she wasn't playing under the Australian flag at the time, Dokic achieved her career-high No.4 ranking following the US Open.

Dokic's career was probably hampered by her well-documented off-court struggles that often involved her father.

After brief hiatus, Dokic returned to the court and went on a tear at the 2009 Australian Open, reaching the quarterfinals and lifting herself back into the top-100.

She retired in 2013, and has since worked as a coach and pundit.

Dokic now works as one of Nine's lead tennis commentators and analysts.

1. Lleyton Hewitt

When Lleyton Hewitt became world No.1 in November 2001, he was the youngest man to ever hold the ranking, a record which would stand until Carlos Alcaraz won the US Open in 2022.

What Hewitt lacked in serving power, he made up for in sheer tenacity. He was incredibly fit, and was known for his ability to make his opponents play an extra shot. He also boasted an incredible volley and one of the best overhead smashes in the game.

His famous 'C'MON' shouts and the accompanying hand gesture were parroted by a generation of kids regardless of the sport they played.

Considering Hewitt was playing at the same time as Pat Rafter and Mark Philippoussis, his time at No.1 was during a golden era of men's tennis in Australia.

The three of them were undoubtedly inspirations to the current crop of Aussie stars including Alex de Minaur, Alexei Popyrin, Thanasi Kokkinakis, and even Ash Barty before them.

Since his retirement from playing, Hewitt has been a captain of the Australian Davis Cup team.

He's also become a mentor to Alex de Minaur, and has dabbled in coaching.

1. Ash Barty

One of the best ambassadors not only for tennis in Australia but sport as a whole, Ashleigh Barty won the hearts of a nation.

She won the junior girls title at Wimbledon in 2011 aged just 15, but was unable to really crack it once she aged out of juniors and went pro.

Barty took two years off and took up cricket, famously playing for the Brisbane Heat in the inaugural WBBL season in 2015-2016.

She returned to tennis a few weeks after the WBBL season wrapped up, and from there her career took off.

She won her first WTA title in Malaysia only 12 months later. She won several others throughout her meteoric rise up the world rankings, and won her first slam at the French Open in 2019. She became No.1 after the Birmingham Classic in the lead up to Wimbledon.

She lost it briefly to Naomi Osaka, but once regaining it with a fourth-round appearance at the US Open, would hold onto it until her retirement in March 2022.

Barty won three slam titles, but it was her Australian Open victory in 2022 that was her crowning moment.

She retired a short time later, stating she had lost the physical drive to remain competitive at the top of world tennis.

Her retirement left a massive hole in Australian tennis, particularly on the women's side.

Barty welcomed a son with her husband Garry Kissick in July 2022.
